Posts.Content: AmyJM wrote: So - I found a lump in my groin area this week, about the size of my port. It's not raised at all, but is about the same size in circumference. After looking it up some, I think it's probably due to a slight rash in the area - I guess an infection can cause an enlarged lymph node in that area, but any kind of mass makes me nervous these days. I called my onc's office and they said to go through my primary care dr first - so I called there and got an appt with a nurse/practitioner tomorrow. I know it's probably not connected to the cancer, but I'm still anxious about it - I'm just hoping it's something simple that has a simple remedy too! Not sure why this post, other than I needed to reach out to my sisters here while I wait and worry. Posts.Title: something new to worry about AmyJM Heidihill

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2013 10:49AM AmyJM wrote: I just got back from seeing the nurse/practitioner. She didn't seem to think it was cancer-related (other than possibly in part due to an already over-taxed system), but wasn't dismissive of it either. She said something about it maybe being a gland, and that it may clear up on it's own. She suggested trying a warm compress on what looked like a blocked follicle and said that might help with the main lump too, even though it's deeper. She said it was moveable and no sign of infection (no fever or redness), so to keep an eye on it for now and come back in a week to have it rechecked. She also said, if there was any change, to feel free to just stop in before that and she'd see me. I'm feeling a little better now since she seemed to think it wasn't cancer-related but is still taking it seriously and monitoring it. It especially helped to know that I could stop in at any time if things got worse. Thanks all for all your support and good wishes - it means a lot! Amy

My dr wants to get an x-ray of it, which they're going to schedule sometime before my next doctor's visit on 11/14. It sounds like there's a good chance that it's nothing - they just want to check it out to be sure. So, the good news is that none of the previous tumors have grown (I think - still have to see the actual report) and the organs are still clear. There's just that little "might be" out there. Posts.Content: AmyJM wrote: Hi All, Along with my regular monthly bloodwork, I had a CA 15-3 test done last month, for the first time since I started treatment after my stage IV diagnosis.Â  I didn't see the results until I went in for my Zometa treatment today though - after the 7 pokes and sending me home last month, I think they didn't think to ask if I wanted a copy of the lab results (and I didn't think to ask).Â  The numbers hadn't been really high to start with (64), but I have been anxious to know which way the numbers are going.Â  So, when the test was done at the beginning of August, after three months of Arimidex and three Zometa treatments, the numbers went from 64 to 33!Â  I know tumor marker tests aren't always really indicative of what's happening - but I figure it's a good sign that the numbers are going down and not up and that the current tx is probably working!!Â  I also used my new port for the first time today - soo much better than all those pokes!!! Also, I need to figure out the insurance piece of it - a long time ago, when he was unemployed for a few months, we did COBRA (which was very expensive), but a friend of mine who knows a lot about navigating the system said that we should look into health insurance from the affordable care act - apparently, even after the enrollment is closed, you can apply for it if you have a change in your financial situation.Â Â  Â We're one of those families that just gets by, paycheck to paycheck (we haven't been able to save up due to a pretty modest income and a fair amt of debt from other times when times were hard).Â  My mom can help us some, but I'm still worried about the future.Â  Hopefully, he'll find something soon (and may be able to do some temp work or a part-time job in the meantime), but there is no guarantee, and I worry about the whole insurance thing - I'm sure there will be some complications and I've no idea what kind of coverage we'll have.Â  It's hard enough dealing with the financial demands of Stage IV, without complications with the insurance!Â  This is so hard on my DH too - I feel so badly for him!Â  I know he'll hit the ground running, looking for a new job, like he did last time, but he's pretty devastated right now.Â  I know we'll get through this, but right now I could use some good thoughts, prayers and support.Â  If you have any words of wisdom you want to send my way too, feel free. Thank you all for being there, Amy A footnote - he hated his job, so this may be a blessing in disguise IF he finds something else soon.Â  That's a pretty big if though, and right now it's pretty scary. Posts.Content: AmyJM wrote: Has anyone else seen this yet? www.storyhalftold.com/about I feel like it's a step in the right direction of awareness of mbc, but it still seemed to me like the profiles of the women painted too cheery a picture - with all of them being so active and (at least seemingly, from their coverage) having such a good QOL still. It's not that I'd want it to be all doom and gloom, just a little more well balanced as to the realities of living with mbc. I know their point was how women with mbc could still "live their lives to the fullest," but it seemed to gloss over the toll it can take. The closest I saw to keeping it real was when Holly mentioned wanting to make memories now that would last a lifetime for her children (the unspoken acknowledgement that she wanted to do it now, because she might not have that much longer to get them in). Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2015 10:43AM AmyJM wrote: I agree Linda. I am one of the ones that is still doing pretty well at this point (except for some joint aches, hot flashes, treatments, scans and the psychological/emotional toll, I'm pretty much able to live my life as always), but I know this isn't true for so many of us, and probably won't always be for me. I'm an optimistic person by nature, and am happy for all that we can do in the midst of this, but I worry that others looking in from the outside, would see this and think mbc must not be so bad - look at all they can do still. It isn't realistic and still is kind of sweeping under the rug the struggles and pain so many go through. I would have liked to have seen profiles where they share their fears, struggles AND ways they are still living in positive ways with mbc.

Posts.Title: Pity Party/Rant Cafelovr

Posts.Content: May 17, 2015 08:27AM - edited May 17, 2015 08:28AM by AmyJM So - I had thought my next onc appt was in a week or two (and that she'd just call in the meantime with scan results) - found out it was this past Friday when I got the reminder call (I'm not always really good at keeping track of that stuff - never miss them, just don't always get them on the calendar and it's usually the last Friday of the month). Anyway, my son and his girlfriend were in town from Virginia, and I had to choose between spending their last day here at the cancer center (appt was at 1, including a zometa treatment, so that would have meant most of the afternoon), or postponing the appt a week and spending the whole day with my kids. I decided I'd rather have the day with them - we only see them twice a year. I've been feeling fine and it's been stable up until now, and even if there is anything new, I figured a week wasn't going to make much difference. It's funny, having made the choice, I'm actually less anxious about getting the results back right away - I might still call early in the week to check, but I think I'd be alright waiting until Friday too. It's going to be another busy week to keep me distracted!

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2016 08:32PM AmyJM wrote: So, since my Stage IV diagnosis, in Spring of 2013, my TM numbers had stayed between 13 - 29 (they had been around 63 when diagnosed stage IV and went down right away with treatment). Last April, they were up to 56, so had a CT/PET scan which showed no progression. At the end of July, my TM numbers were up to 84, so another scan this coming Tuesday. Depending on what it shows, I may stay on Arimedex or may switch to Faslodex/Ibrance. I'd been holding steady for three years (not NED, but no progression either), but I'm really worried about it this time. There 's something about the first progression - really takes you out of denial-land and drives home the point that I can't just stay in a holding pattern forever.
Posts.Title: Having a scan? Waiting on results? The waiting room is open! exbrnxgrl gramen

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2016 09:58PM AmyJM wrote: So, I looked online this morning and it had the results from yesterday's scans. It basically said that the lesions had not increased in size or number, but they have become more active since the last scan. I got a call from my onc's NP today and she said it wasn't a big concern (the way she put it was that it "wasn't anything to write home about") but said that my onc decided it was time to switch treatments, to stay on top of things. So, no more Arimidex and starting this Friday, it's on to Faslodex/Ibrance. I have very mixed emotions - I'm glad it didn't spread, but there's still the whole psychological/emotional thing about changing treatments for the first time. And, even though she said most folks tolerate the Faslodex/Ibrance fairly well, I'm pretty sure it won't be as easy as the Arimidex was. The only side effect I really had from that was occasional hot flashes, and possibly making my arthritis a little worse.

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2016 08:24PM AmyJM wrote: Artist, I had CT and Bone scans when I had insurance that wouldn't cover the PET scan. My understanding of it was that the CT and Bone scans showed what was there, and the PET scan showed where any active cancer was. I think the CT scans will show if there is anything new, but might not show what is active or not in what was already there. For instance, when I finally had a PET scan, it showed that some of the mets in my spine that still showed up were inactive. IMO, the PET is more thorough of a representation of what is going on, but the CT scan (in my case, I had a bone scan too - not sure if you are) is the next best thing and probably sufficient to see whether or not there is progression. Good luck - I will be thinking of you tomorrow! Hugs, Amy

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2015 06:47PM - edited Mar 26, 2015 06:49PM by AmyJM Allyme, You've already been given a lot of good advice and support here. I just wanted to add that I so agree with what Penny, you and others have said about good coming from the bad. One of my favorite verses in the Bible is Romans 8:28 "We know that in everything, God works for good with those who love him, who are called according to his purpose." In no way do I consider having cancer a blessing or anything I would ever have wanted to happen (and I don't believe that God wanted it to happen or caused it either), but there have been blessings that have come from it, including a deeper faith and being able to be there in a much more meaningful way for other women I knew or met who were diagnosed with bc after I was. To me, the verse means that God is always working for the good, and can take anything, no matter how bad it is, and bring good from it. As far as God watching over you, I've always felt that God's love is like that of a parent - not stepping in to always make everything go right, but rejoicing with us when they do and there to hold us up and give love and support when they don't. In my opinion, God is still right there with you. Fitzwins - thanks for recommending the book, A Grace Disguised. It looks like a good one. I've read When Bad things Happen to Good People, but not this other - I think I may look into it. Sending love and prayers and hugs to you, Allyme, and to all my bco sisters, Amy

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2013 11:57PM AmyJM wrote: Hi, I'm new around here - in fact, this is my first post.Â  I've been reading posts since my recurrance (it's been a great place to come to find answers for all my questions), so I feel like I've already gotten so much support/info here, but haven't introduced myself yet.Â  I was first diagnosed with BC in 2003 - had a mastectomy (right side), 6 months of chemo and 5 years of Tamoxifen and thought/hoped that maybe I was in the clear, until my tumor marker numbers were up this year.Â  I think hearing that was almost worse than when I finally got the diagnosis - it's like your worst nightmare, that it'll come back one day (and after 9 years out from treatment, you get a false sense of security).Â  By the time everything was confirmed, I pretty much knew what the results were going to be though.Â  It took a couple months (ah, the "fun" of the waiting game again) to get through meeting with a new oncologist (my orignial onc had retired), waiting for the insurance company to drag their feet and then deny coverage of the PET-CT scan, then having the reg CT Scan and bone scan, and then biopsy to finally get the official diagnosis -Â  BC mets on my lower spine and right hip.Â  I'm on Arimidex and Zometa and still adjusting to my new reality.Â  It's been a real roller-coaster, as all of you know, I'm sure.Â  Anyway, to get to the reason for this post (other than introducing myself and rambling on), I live in Grand Rapids, MI and would really like to meet folks from here - everyone seems so friendly and supportive - and you all "get it."Â  I"m hoping to come to the picnic (with husband in tow) and look forward to meeting some of you! Amy

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2016 10:37PM AmyJM wrote: I finally finished the book too. I really liked it. I would definitely recommend it to others. In fact, my book group is meeting for dinner, later this month, to choose books for next year, and I'm going to recommend this one. I agree with a lot of what others said about it. I agree with how important a "community" is in one's life. It "saved" him more than once and he, in turn, made such a difference in the lives of others. I thought he was endearing, even though he didn't come across that way to most - I'd never thought about the possibility of Aspergers (and the author probably didn't either is my guess), but I can see that. I also thought he was a lot older - maybe because he was portrayed as an old man - and being in my 50's, I don't feel old! One thing that wasn't addressed in the questions, that I thought this book also portrayed, was the influence others have on us and how they shape who we are. Whenever he felt disinclined to help others, he usually came around when he thought about what his father would have done or how it would have made his wife feel. I'm sure he made a big impact on the lives of those he helped too.

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2013 02:38PM AmyJM wrote: I think that the ones that think they are "cured" sometimes feel like they have to find a reason why ours came back and theirs didn't - we must have done something "wrong" that they didn't - because it's too terrifying to think it might come back for them.Â  I think I read on a thread (or a link from a thread) here somewhere - that when cancer cells break off that will later metasticize, it usually happens early on, when the original tumor is still very small (and that it doesn't just go through the lymph nodes). So, I would think that no matter how early the tumor is caught or what the treatment is, no one is immune from a recurrence.Â  Most folks that think they are "cured" can't handle that idea though. Noquitter - your situation is so similar to mine - I was also 43 the first time around (2003 - stage llla, mastectomy on the right side, 6 mos. of chemo but no radiation) - thought I was free and clear after 5 years - only to have the stage IV diagnosis this past May, almost 10 years later.Â  I can so relate to everything you've said!Â  I'm sorry you had to deal with the self-righteous "cured" co-worker.Â  I really do think she's just scared to death to entertain the thought that it could ever come back for her. I want the whole Elephant line too - the elephant slapper, the mug - and the t-shirt sounds great!Â  I think the elephant slapper should be stuffed or like a rubber chicken or a dog toy or something. : ) Amy
